content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Design attributed to Peter L. Berg (American, born Norway, 1885–1959)  
Kalo Shop (American, 1900–1970)  
Park Ridge, Illinois, or Chicago, Illinois  
Silver  
Each 16.5 × 30.5 × 21 cm (6 1/2 × 12 × 8 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, restricted gift of Louise Ingersoll Tausché, 2014.997.1–2

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">During Kalo’s early years, founder Clara Barck Welles was said to have designed all the shop’s metalwork. By 1910, however, most of Welles’s silversmiths were Scandinavian-trained and had therefore completed a curriculum including studies in design as well as fabrication. Indeed, the elegant ovoid shape of the Art Institute’s pair of covered footed dishes recalls the work of Danish silversmith Georg Jensen. Only their hammered surfaces and straplike handles attest to their Chicago origins. Their design is likely by the Norwegian-trained Peter Lauritz Berg, who joined the shop in 1909.

From his earliest years at Kalo, Berg, who would become foreman in 1918, kept small notebooks of drawings for vessels. Dating from c. 1909 to the mid-1920s, these sketches form the basis of the attribution of the Art Institute’s covered dishes. Berg’s drawings are mainly simple, small-format sketches in graphite on the five-by three-inch pages of pocket notebooks. Each side of nearly every sheet includes sketches and notations for as many as six objects. Occasionally, Berg names the client; sometimes, he gives the date an item was commissioned or perhaps due to be completed. In a few instances, he mentions a specific silversmith. Most often included are the weight of the silver and the number of hours necessary to execute the design. One of these pages features a sketch for the Art Institute’s oval dishes (see fig. 81.1). Berg estimates on this sheet that the pair of dishes required “around 65 hrs” to produce.

In addition to authoring their design, Berg may have also fabricated the dishes in collaboration with another silversmith; a second drawing depicting a similar, although round, covered footed dish specifically notes that he spent, or would spend, twenty-eight hours on the project, while an as of yet unidentified silversmith named “Mollender” spent, or was to spend, fourteen hours. Fitting the round bowl with dividers for three compartments required an additional nine hours, a task not assigned to a particular silversmith.

The covered dishes are datable to the years 1912 to 1917, a period when Kalo operated a shop in New York in addition to its Chicago retail location. Buoyed by continuing success, Welles opened the Kalo outpost at 718 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, engendering the addition of “New York” to Kalo’s mark, as appears on the dishes. Welles moved the shop to a second New York address in 1916 but closed it the following year, coincident with the United States’ entrance into World War I. The call to national service of some of her silversmiths, together with the rationing of precious metals in the war effort, would seem to have played a significant part in Kalo’s retreat to Chicago.

During the New York years, Kalo’s design inventory expanded in response to the taste of its new clientele, who were discovering the work of Jensen and other Scandinavian silversmiths. Searches of New York newspapers of the period indicate that Welles did not alter her minimalist marketing philosophy. According to one longtime employee, “Mrs. Welles said the best advertising was good work and good service to your customers.”  
Barbara K. Schnitzer
